title: Protocol for cryopreservation of red blood cells that controls ice crystal formation by fulvic acid
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Effect of FA on ice crystal growth
Timing: 1 h
      This section provides an overview of the inhibitory effect of FA on ice
      crystal growth under rapid cooling conditions.
    
Prepare FA PBS solution (120 mg mL−1).
Note: The pH of FA PBS solution was
      adjusted to 7.4, and the solution was stored at 4°C when not use.
    
Add 10 μL FA PBS to the center of the cleaned coverslip.
Note: We use microscope coverslips with a
      size of 24 × 24 mm and a thickness of 0.13–0.16 mm. For the coverslips in
      all experiments, make sure that they are cleaned to prevent impurities
      from affecting the formation of ice crystals.
    
        Cover another piece of cleaned coverslip on the top of FA PBS solution
        to allow the liquid to diffuse evenly and obtain a sandwich structure as
        shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig1.jpg
              Figure 1. Effect of FA on ice crystal growth during cooling stage
            
(A) Optical image of the FA sandwich structure.
              (B) Optical image of FA sandwich structure after freezing in
              cryostage.
            
(C) Micrograph of ice crystals in PBS solution.
(D) Micrograph of ice crystals in FA PBS solution.
Note: Do not use external pressure to
      prevent the sample from being squeezed out.
    
        Place the double-layer glass sandwiched with FA PBS on the cryostage, as
        shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B.
      
        Freeze FA PBS liquid samples by decreasing the temperature of hermetic
        cryostage from room temperature to −120°C at various cooling rates at a
        constant pressure of 1 atm (typically ≥ 20°C min−1 to
        simulate the rapid cooling condition during cryopreservation in this
        work).
      
        Take images of ice crystals after freezing through a digital camera
        connected to the microscope, as shown in Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C
        and 1D.
      
        Measure the size of ice crystals by Image J software.

Turn on the micrograph by Image J software.
Set up the corresponding scale.
Measure the length of 200–300 ice crystals.
Order the data of ice crystal sizes from largest to smallest.
            Calculate the mean and standard deviation of the first 60 data.
          
Effect of FA on ice crystal recrystallization
Timing: 1 h
      This section describes the steps and precautions for ice recrystallization
      experiments.
    
Prepare FA PBS solution (same as step 1).
Place a piece of clean coverslip on cryostage.
Close the sealing cover of cryostage.
Cooling the temperature of cryostage to −60°C.
Wait for 30 s.
Note: Narrow the temperature gap between
      the coverslip and cryostage.
    
Open the cryostage sealing cover.
        Drop 10 μL FA PBS solutions onto the pre-cooled coverslip by splat
        cooling method.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2] The operation details are shown in
        Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. Process and corresponding results of the
              recrystallization experiment
            
              (A) Optical image of dropping liquid sample by splat cooling
              method.
            
(B) Optical image of FA PBS after freezing in cryostage.
              (C and D) Polarized micrograph of ice crystals growth in PBS
              (C) solution and FA PBS (D) solution after annealing at −8°C for
              45 min.
            
Note: The splat cooling method is a
      classic assay to study whether a material has the ability to inhibit ice
      recrystallization. The FA PBS solution was dropped from a height of about
      1.2 meters, in order to make the solution freeze instantly and uniformly,
      which is favorable for the following microscopic observation and crystal
      size statistic because the formed ice crystals are homogeneous in size and
      thin in thickness.
    
        Close the cryostage sealing cover, as shown in
        Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B.
      
Critical: See
      troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
    
Wait for 30 s.
Note: Ensure that the liquid sample is
      completely frozen.
    
        Heat the temperature of cryostage to −8°C at a rate of 5°C min−1

and hold for 45 min.
      
        Photograph the ice flake through a digital camera connected to the
        microscope, as shown in Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C and 2D.
      
        Measure the ice crystal size by Image J software (same as step 7).
      
Effect of FA on ice crystal melting
Timing: 1 h
      This section describes the specific operation of DSC test and in-situ
      observation of ice crystals melting by optical microscope.
    
        Prepare FA (240 mg mL−1) and Suc (267 mg mL−1, the
        approximately equal molar concentration compared with FA) PBS solutions.
      
        The solution was prepared into a sandwich structure as shown in
        Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A.
      
Place the sample on cryostage.
Freeze liquid sample at various cooling rates.
Heat the cryostage at a rate of 5°C min−1.
Ice crystals gradually melt.
        High-frame video of the heating process was captured by a camera
        connected to the microscope.
      
        Capture the melting state of ice crystals at different temperatures
        during the heating process, as shown in
        Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A−3F.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig3.jpg
              Figure 3. Effect of FA on ice crystal melting
            
              (A–C) Polarized micrograph of ice crystal melting of FA PBS at
              −20°C (A), −6.8°C (B), and −4.5°C (C).
            
              (D–F) Polarized micrograph of ice crystal melting of Suc PBS at
              −20°C (D), −6.8°C (E), and −3.3°C (F).
            
              (G) DSC curves of FA and Suc, inset shows the melting temperature
              at different cooling rates.
            
        Prepare two hermetic aluminum crucibles with the same quality (with
        sealing cover).
      
        Add 2 μL of liquid sample with a pipette to one of the hermetic aluminum
        crucibles and the other is the reference.
      
Seal the two aluminum crucibles.
        Put them into differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) instrument sample
        holder.
      
        Set the temperature program.
        
Heat the sample from room temperature to 40°C.
Cool down to 30°C rapidly.
Cool down to −60°C at a series of cooling rates.
Wait for 1 min.

Heat up to 30°C.
Wait for 1 min.
Note: Each sample was measured three
      cycles (from step b to step f).
    
        Plot DSC curves and record the melting temperatures at different cooling
        rates, as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G.
      
Effect of FA on ice shape
Timing: 3 h
      As ice-shaping effect is not desired in cryopreservation, we studied
      growth behaviors of ice crystals including morphology and growth rate by a
      nanolite osmometer.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Prepare FA aqueous solution (120 mg mL−1).
        Calibrate otago nanolite osmometer with Milli-Q water and NaCl solution.
      
        A submicroliter volume of sample was injected into a
        temperature-controlled sample holder full of immersion oil Type B using
        a microinjector.
      
Cooling the sample holder rapidly to freeze the aqueous solution.
Warm slowly.
Critical: The purpose of slow heating
      is to prevent the ice crystals from completely melting.
    
        Find a disk-shaped ice crystal with a diameter of 15 μm, as shown in
        Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A and 4B.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig4.jpg
              Figure 4. Effect of FA on ice crystal growth and shape in Milli-Q
              water and FA aqueous solution
            
              (A and B) Micrograph of ice crystal at the initial time of Milli-Q
              water (A) and FA aqueous solution (B).
            
              (C and D) Micrograph of ice crystal of Milli-Q water (C) and FA
              aqueous solution (D) after 30 s.
            
Note: It should be noted that we need to
      confirm the melting temperature (TM), that is, the temperature
      at which the single ice crystal will not melt and grow within 20 s.
    
        Adjust the temperature to the desired value (TF) according to
        the required supercooling temperature.
      
Note: We define the supercooling
      temperature ΔT = TF – TM.
    
        Take images of ice crystals through a high-speed camera connected to the
        microscope, as shown in Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C and 4D.
      
        Compare the sizes and shapes of ice crystals in various solutions.

Cytocompatibility of FA
Timing: 24 h
      This section describes the details of the experimental manipulation of FA
      cytocompatibility tests4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] and the considerations.
    
        Prepare FA PBS solution of double desired concentrations (same as step
        1).
      
Note: FA PBS solution with target
      concentration was obtained by mixing the FA PBS solution of double target
      concentration and PBS buffer with equal volume.
    
Note: We do not list the specific
      concentrations of FA PBS solutions because a range of concentrations were
      used in the experiments.
    
        Pretreatment of RBCs (see
        materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
      
        RBCs dispersion was blended with the prepared FA PBS solution (in step
        43) in equal volume, as shown in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig5.jpg
              Figure 5. Preparation and incubation of FA RBCs
            
(A) Optical image of FA PBS and RBC mixture.
(B) Optical image of FA RBCs incubate at 4°C.
Critical: The operator, operating
      environment and outer walls of the bottle containing RBCs should be
      disinfected with 75% medical alcohol before each operation. All the mix
      and transfer process of FA RBCs must be carried out in the biosafety
      cabinet, level-II to prevent microbial contamination. All experiments
      involving RBCs in the following need to be operated in biosafety cabinet,
      level-II.
    
Critical: We placed the cryovials on
      ice pack during the whole process of FA RBC preparation to reduce the
      possibility of cell hemolysis.
    
Mix FA and RBCs dispersion evenly with a vortex mixer.
Critical: Uniform the mixture of FA
      and RBCs by vortex mixer at a low speed to prevent the mechanical damage
      of RBCs.
    
        Prepare RBCs dispersion of target concentration (control group).
        
            100% hemolytic samples: RBC dispersion was blended with Milli-Q
            water of equal volume. If necessary, RBCs can be further broken by
            ultrasonication.
          
            0% hemolytic samples: RBC dispersion was blended with PBS buffer of
            equal volume, shaken gently and mixed evenly.

Pause point: If needed, ensure that
      all RBCs belong to samples purchased at the same time. Further considering
      the change in cell viability over time, fresh RBCs i.e., samples with the
      shortest time since purchase were used as much as possible.
    
        The evenly mixed FA RBCs dispersion was placed in a refrigerator at 4°C
        to incubate for 24 h, as shown in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B.
      
Cryopreservation of RBCs
Timing: 5 h
      This section describes the experimental operation rules of RBCs
      cryopreservation, which is the core part of this protocol.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
Prepare FA PBS solution (same as step 42).
Note: Prepare HES PBS, Suc PBS and
      D-galactose PBS solution in the same way.
    
        Pretreatment of RBCs (see
        materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
      
Mix RBCs and FA PBS in cryogenic vials (same as step 45).
        Uniform the mixture of FA and RBC by vortex mixer (same as step 46).
      
        After mixing, all samples were placed on ice pack, as shown in
        Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig6.jpg
              Figure 6. Cryopreservation of FA RBCs
            
(A) Optical image of preparation of FA RBCs.
(B) Optical image of fixing FA RBCs to foam well plate.
              (C) Optical image of FA RBCs in liquid nitrogen, inset shows the
              sealed container.
            
              (D and E) Optical images of FA RBCs thawed at 4°C (D) and 45°C
              (E).
            
        Fix cryogenic vials to foam floating plate (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
      
        Transfer the fixed samples to a container containing liquid nitrogen (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C).
      
Alternatives: The container in
      this context can be replaced with any container capable of holding liquid
      nitrogen.
    
Note: We chose this cooling system due to
      the operability of the experiment and the relationship between
      cryopreservation temperature-cryopreservation effects.6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
Critical: All samples must be quickly
      transferred to liquid nitrogen to prevent the cooling rate from affecting
      the cell survival.
    
Cover the lid of the tank containing liquid nitrogen.

Maintain for 2.5 h.
        Thaw the frozen samples.
        
Note: Recrystallization of ice
          crystals during thawing process can lead to severe cell damage.
        
            Refrigerator was used to provide a thawing environment of 4°C (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]D).
          
            Homemade thermostatic water bath was used to provide a thawing
            environment of 45°C (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]E).
          
Critical: The thawing time must be
      strictly controlled to prevent the damage of RBCs from high temperature.
      In our experiment, we found that 1 min was sufficient for complete melting
      of the ice phase.
    
        Prepare control group (same as steps 43 and 47).
        
100% hemolysis samples.
0% hemolysis samples.
FA PBS solution.
        FA RBCs thawed at 45°C were placed in a refrigerator at 4°C for various
        time of incubation.
      
Note: Verify the effect of post-thaw
      culture time on cell recovery.
    
Measurement of cell recovery
Timing: 2 h
      This section describes the procedure for testing the recovery of RBCs
      after cryopreservation and the considerations.
    
Dilute FA RBCs (40 μL FA RBC was added to 400 μL PBS buffer).
        Uniform the mixture of FA and RBCs by vortex mixer (same as step 46).
      
        Prepare control group such as 100% hemolysis RBCs, 0% hemolysis RBCs and
        FA PBS (the dilution ratio is the same as in step 61).
      
        All the samples were centrifuged at 275 × g for 5 min at 4°C to
        remove intact cells, as shown in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig7.jpg
              Figure 7. Measurement of cell recovery
            
(A) Optical image of FA PBS centrifugation treatment.
              (B and C) Optical images of FA RBCs before (B) and after
              (C) centrifugation.
            
(D) Optical image of supernatant in 96 well plates.
              (E) Optical image of absorbance measured by microplate reader.
            
        The state of FA RBCs before (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B) and after
        (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C) centrifugation.
      
Collect the supernatant.
        Transfer the supernatant to 96 well plates, as shown in

Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]D.
      
Note: All samples were vortexed to
      maintain the homogeneity.
    
        The absorbance at the wavelength of 415 nm was measured with a
        microplate reader, as shown in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]E.
      
        Cell recovery was calculated by subtracting the attained hemolysis (%)
        from 100 (%).
      
Critical: The details of the
      calculation can be found in troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
    
Measure the number of intact RBCs by blood analyzer.
Note: We can roughly calculate the cell
      recovery by comparing the number of structurally intact cells before and
      after cryopreservation. The measurement does not require any pretreatment
      of the sample, but it is necessary to ensure the consistency of the sample
      amount and the cleanness of the test instrument probe during the
      operation.
    
Measurement of cell viability
Timing: 3 h
      In this section, we first validate the feasibility of flow cytometric
      assay in measuring the viability of RBCs, followed describe detailed
      experimental operation of viability measurement of FA RBCs after
      cryopreservation.
    
        Prepare sodium azide (NaN3, 0.05%) solution with PBS as
        solvent.
      
Critical: NaN3 is a highly
      toxic substance. Operation process and precautions are detailed in
      troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
    
        Mix fresh RBCs and NaN3 solution (same as steps 45 and 46 and
        71).
      
Incubate the mixture at 4°C for different time.
Obtain RBCs with different viability.
Clean RBCs.
Note: Removal of unreacted NaN3
      and lysed RBCs.
    
        The purchased calcein-AM was diluted using PBS buffer into the
        concentration of 100 μM as the working solution.
      
Note: Calcein-AM can penetrate the cell
      membrane of living cells and convert into membrane impermeable calcein by
      cytolactonase, which can emit bright green fluorescence and be retained by
      cells with intact membrane. For dead or damaged cells with impaired
      membrane integrity, calcein-AM or calcein can be rapidly excreted from the
      cells.
    
        Mix RBCs (400 μL, 5 × 105 cells) and calcein-AM (20 μL).

Uniform the mixture of RBCs and calcein-AM by vortex mixer (same as step
        46).
      
        The mixture was incubated at 37°C for 45 min in the dark to ensure
        calcein-AM can fully react with RBCs.
      
        The incubated sample was measured immediately by flow cytometer with the
        channel of FITC. The mesured results of RBCs with different viabilities
        are shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8].
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2534-Fig8.jpg
              Figure 8. Results of RBC viability after different time of NaN3
              treatment
            
              Copyright 2022.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Adopted with permission from
              Elsevier Science Ltd.
            
        Measure the viability7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] of RBCs after
        cryopreservation, the specific operation is the same as steps 75−80.
      
Set control group.
Note: Fresh RBCs with/without calcein-AM
      staining.
